page.title: 11Wildlife in Cranbrook
page.content: There is probably a wider variety of wildlife in Cranbrook now than there was 50 years ago.With the continual building of houses and the encroachment of the surrounding countryside,the felling of copses and woods,and scrubbing of hedgerows,the animals have addapt to living nearer to people.It is common sight to see squirrels in the tall trees surrounding the churchyard. But by the library there is a small pond formed by water from a pipe.A large variety of birds can be seen playing and bathing in the trickle of water,especially sparrows,starlings, blackbirds and thrushes.There seems to be a thriving population of rabbits and hedgehogs leaving telltale signs of their presence.Snakes and slow-worms can be seen bobbing in the sun in the churchyard.Foxes rummage through bins at night looking for scraps.
